title: Address Resolution
description: Understanding ARP, MAC address tables, and address resolution protocols

keyConcepts.title: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol)
keyConcepts.description: Protocol that maps a known Layer 3 IPv4 address to an unknown Layer 2 MAC address on the same local network. Essential for frame encapsulation.

keyConcepts.title: ARP Process
keyConcepts.description: Host broadcasts an ARP Request (destination MAC: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF) asking 'Who has IP x.x.x.x?'. The target responds with an ARP Reply containing its MAC address.

keyConcepts.title: ARP Table/Cache
keyConcepts.description: Stores IPv4-to-MAC address mappings in RAM. Contains both dynamic entries (learned via ARP) and static entries (permanent mappings like broadcast addresses).

keyConcepts.title: IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (NDP)
keyConcepts.description: IPv6 replacement for ARP. Uses ICMPv6 Neighbor Solicitation and Neighbor Advertisement messages instead of ARP Request/Reply.

keyConcepts.title: Switch MAC Address Table
keyConcepts.description: Layer 2 switches learn source MAC addresses and their associated ports. When destination MAC is unknown, the switch floods the frame out all ports except the ingress port.

keyConcepts.title: Router Components
keyConcepts.description: RAM stores running config, routing table, and ARP cache (volatile). NVRAM stores startup config (non-volatile). Flash stores IOS. ROM stores bootstrap and basic diagnostics.

importantPoints: ARP maps Layer 3 IPv4 addresses to Layer 2 MAC addresses
ARP only works on the same local network/subnet
ARP Request uses broadcast MAC address: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
ARP Reply is unicast directly to the requesting host
ARP table is stored in RAM (volatile memory)
Command 'arp -a' displays the ARP cache on Windows/Linux
Static ARP entries include broadcast addresses (e.g., 192.168.1.255 → FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF)
For remote destinations, ARP resolves the MAC of the default gateway/router
IPv6 uses Neighbor Solicitation/Advertisement (NDP) instead of ARP
Switches flood unknown unicast frames out all ports except the ingress port
Switches flood broadcast frames out all ports except the ingress port
RAM holds: routing table, ARP cache, running-config
ROM holds: bootstrap program and POST diagnostics
